subcat_1.title: Get Money Wise

task_1.title: Open a bank account in your name.

task_2.title: Set aside money for living expenses and to hire an attorney.

task_3.title: Set aside money for living expenses and to hire an attorney.

task_5.title: Open two credit cards in your name.

task_1.title: Employment Information
task_1.description: Paycheck stubs for you and your spouse for the last 12 months (or at least the last three months to the current date).

task_2.title: Tax Returns
task_2.description: Last three years of state and federal income tax returns.

task_3.title: Pension/Retirement Programs
task_3.description: Copies of 401K, investment programs, stock, stock options, bonds provided through the employer for both you and/or your spouse.

task_4.title: Insurance
task_4.description: Documents regarding insurance provided through the employer for both you and/or your spouse.

task_5.title: Real Property
task_5.description: Deeds showing the legal description of any real property owned individually or jointly with your spouse, escrow papers from the time of purchase, information from lender showing current mortgage balances, monthly payments, loan numbers, current real property tax statements, homeowners or fire insurance policies on all real properties, tax assessors statements.

task_6.title: Stock Portfolio
task_6.description: List of corporate stocks and/or stock certificates owned by you and your spouse, individually or jointly, the name and address of stock broker(s).

task_7.title: Cars, boats, trailers
task_7.description: Copies of pink and registration slips, encumbrance (what’s owed), monthly payment.

task_8.title: Life Insurance
task_8.description: Current policies with statements of any loans against them.

task_9.title: Promissory Notes and/or Deeds of Trust
task_9.description: Copies of such records that name you and your spouse as beneficiaries.

task_10.title: Credit Cards, Loans
task_10.description:
Credit cards, creditor’s statements showing names, address account numbers, and balances presently owed. Creditor’s statements showing balances owed at separation date.
Financial statements of net worth prepared by you or your spouse for the purpose of securing bank loans or for any other purpose. Any other information that will help establish the net worth individually or jointly, for you and your spouse.

task_11.title: Household Furniture/Furnishings
task_11.description: Pictures and/or your opinion of the estimated value. You may be asked to list those items which you wish to keep and those which you wish to give to your spouse.

task_12.title: Bank/Credit Union Accounts
task_12.description: Most recent statements showing balances, particularly at date of separation, held in individual or joint names, savings passbooks, Certificates of Deposit.

task_14.title: Written Agreements
task_14.description:
* Premarital, postmarital written agreements with spouse.
* Corporate, partnership federal and state income tax returns for the last three years.
* Copies of recent financial statements prepared to apply for credit or business loans of any kind.

subcat_1.title: Find a Divorce Financial Planner

task_1.title: Questions to Ask the  Divorce Financial Planner
task_1.description:
* When did you receive your certification as a CFP, CDFA or CPA?
* Do you have a specific background in taxation or accounting?
* How many divorce cases have you completed?
* Do you have experience in complex property divisions, and if so, will you illustrate multiple scenarios?
* Are you familiar with calculations regarding employee stock options, restricted stock and/or executive compensation?
* Can I see a sample of the written divorce financial plan you provide to your clients?
* When is the last time you testified in court?
* Are your credentials or licensing subject to review by government or regulatory agencies?
* Do you have any disciplinary events, suspensions, or violations on your record under this or any other name?
* Are you currently licensed and in compliance with all appropriate governing regulatory agencies?
* If you are not subject to the above criteria, what qualifies you as a divorce financial expert?

task_1.title: Make 100% of your payments on time.

task_2.title: Don’t let your debt balance exceed 30% of your credit limit.

task_3.title: Avoid opening too many new accounts at once.

task_4.title: Keep accounts open for as long as possible.

task_5.title: Check each of your credit reports annually for errors and discrepancies.

task_1.title: Mortgage statement

task_2.title: Property Tax statement

task_3.title: Homeowner’s Insurance statement

task_5.title: Home maintenance checks, credit card statements, and receipts
task_5.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_6.title: Home Repairs checks and credit card statements and receipts (total year prior to date of separation)

task_7.title: Utilities statements (total year prior to date of separation)

task_8.title: Phone, Cable, Internet statements (total year prior to date of separation)

task_9.title: Automobile Expenses (total car payment, gas, service records for year prior to date of separation)

task_11.title: Unreimbursed Medical Expenses records total year prior to date of separation
task_11.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation

task_12.title: Food at Home expenses
task_12.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_13.title: Food Eating Out expenses
task_13.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_14.title: Dry cleaning receipts
task_14.description: total year prior to date of separation

task_15.title: Clothing expenses
task_15.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_16.title: Personal expenses
task_16.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_17.title: Fitness expenses
task_17.description: Determine from total account withdrawals for membership.

task_18.title: Entertainment expenses
task_18.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_19.title: Gifts
task_19.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_20.title: Vacations
task_20.description: Determine from total year prior to date of separation.

task_21.title: Charitable Contributions
task_21.description: Includes average from last 3 years’ income tax returns.

task_22.title: Savings, Investment, Retirement
task_22.description: Includes total contributions year prior to date of separation.

task_23.title: Miscellaneous
task_23.description: Includes any other expenses in support of your marital standard of living.

subcat_1.title: How to Handle the Suddenly Income Deficient Spouse (SIDS)

task_1.title: Gather personal and business tax returns for the last three years and if possible, documentation of the business’s financials

task_2.title: If you do not have access to this information, discuss with your attorney the need to take discovery to obtain it

task_3.title: Ask your attorney whether it is advisable to retain a forensic accountant to assist with the preparation and review of information obtained through discovery

task_4.title: Factor into your divorce budget the cost of discovery and bringing a forensic on the team

task_5.title: If your husband is earning less than before or is suddenly unemployed, consider conducting a vocational evaluation

subcat_1.title: Attorney Fees—When and How to Obtain an Order That Your Husband Pay Your Attorney Fees

task_1.title: If your spouse earns more than you do, ask your attorney whether you qualify for an attorney’s fee order under the laws of your state

task_2.title: If there is misconduct in your case by the other side, ask your attorney whether you qualify for attorney’s fees as a sanction

subcat_1.title: When to Hire a Forensic Accountant

task_1.title: When one spouse is suspected of concealing income or assets

task_2.title: When there is a closely held business or a highly-compensated spouse

task_3.title: When assessing the tax ramification of a proposed settlement

subcat_1.title: Take Control of Your Finances

task_1.title: The 50/30/20 Plan
task_1.description:
1. Calculate Your After-Tax Income
2. Limit Your Needs to 50 Percent
3. Limit Your Wants to 30 Percent
4. Spend at Least 20 Percent on Savings and Debt Repayments

task_2.title: Use a Financial Advisor
task_2.description:
* Commission Based Financial Planners
* Fee Based Financial Planners
* Fee Only Financial Planners

task_3.title: Invest
task_3.description:
* Need the money in 1-2 years? Short-term investments are appropriate: money markets, CD’s, saving accounts
* Need the money in 2-3 years? Lower risk investments, such as short-term bonds
* Need the money in 4-5 years? You can add some risk investments into the portfolio (stocks)

subcat_1.title: Organize Your Financial Affairs

task_1.title: Obtain a copy of your certified divorce decree

task_2.title: Research your health insurance options
task_2.description:
* Keep your ex-spouse’s coverage for a limited time (up to 36 months) through COBRA.
* Find your own insurance policy. Open enrollment for health insurance doesn’t begin again until the end of the year, but you’re likely eligible for a plan under a Special Enrollment Period, since a change in health coverage stemming from a divorce is a qualifying event.
* Start coverage with your employer. Like open enrollment, your divorce qualifies you to sign up for coverage even if it’s outside your workplace’s enrollment period.

task_3.title: Execute documents to transfer the title to property. (real estate, automobiles, boats, etc.)

task_4.title: Establish a system to keep track of all child support made/received, alimony payments made/received, and medical expenses

task_5.title: Consider establishing direct deposit or income withholding. (child support, spousal support and/or alimony payments)

task_7.title: Update accounts
task_7.description:
* Social Security Card
* Driver’s license
* Passport
* Credit cards

task_8.title: Remove your husband’s name and/or change your name/address on all remaining accounts, including:
task_8.description:
* Bank, brokerage and investment accounts
* Employer’s records
* IRS records
* Life, health, homeowner’s and disability insurance policies
* Post office (Remember to have your mail forwarded if you are moving.)
* Professional licenses
* Utility bills
* Children’s school(s)

task_9.title: Update beneficiaries on the following plans:

subcat_1.title: Know the Three Ways to Get Divorced

task_1.title: Mediation

task_2.title: Collaborative Approach

task_3.title: Traditional Litigation

task_1.title: Ask your divorced friends for referrals
task_1.description:
Ask the following questions:
* How much did the attorney charge for a retainer(the amount to start the case) and how much did they charge per hour?
* Did the lawyer return their calls and emails within 24 hours?
* How happy was your friend with the amount of support ordered and the division of assets?
* How did the lawyer handle issues concerning children?
* How often did the lawyer go to court and were they effective in obtaining the relief sought?
* Did the lawyer do a good job preparing your friend for court appearances?
* Will the lawyer allow you to negotiate directly with your husband Did the lawyer send a monthly bill that was easy to understand and in the range anticipated?
* If not, how did the lawyer handle questions about the bill?
* Does the lawyer have a paralegal or assistant who will handle the clerical tasks at a lower rate than the attorney?
* How long did the divorce take?

task_2.title: Ask your therapist for referrals

task_3.title: Make appointments to interview three divorce lawyers

subcat_1.title: Retain Counsel

task_1.title: Questions to Ask the Lawyer
task_1.description:
* How many years have you practiced family law?;How many divorces have you handled?
* What is the average length of time between filing for divorce and resolution? How long does your average case take?
* What percentage of your cases go to trial?
* How many cases have you tried?
* How much do you charge per hour?
* What is your retainer?
* How do you bill?
* Can I pay by credit card?
* When do you recommend using formal discovery?
* Will I need a forensic accountant and if so, who do you recommend?

subcat_1.title: Consider How to Serve the Divorce Papers

task_1.title: Notice of Acknowledgment and Receipt
task_1.description: The least aggravating way to serve divorce papers is by Notice of Acknowledgement and Receipt. A form is sent by mail with the Summons and Petition and your spouse signs and returns it. But this only works if he is willing to cooperate.

task_2.title: Process Server
task_2.description: If you are concerned that your husband may drain the bank accounts or dissipate marital assets, you need to have him served immediately by a process server.

task_3.title: Pick up
task_3.description: If you are mediating your divorce, then typically the mediator will prepare the petition and summons, have you come in to sign the papers and then have your husband come in to pick them up, thus effectuating service.

subcat_1.title: Prepare Your Financial Disclosures

task_1.title: Calendar a deadline in four weeks to have a draft prepared to submit to your attorney for review

task_2.title: For your income and expense declaration, use your current and anticipated monthly expenses for your household, which includes you and anyone who is living with you

task_3.title: Review utility payments and other fluctuating payments over the last twelve months and come up with a monthly average for your expense statement

task_4.title: List all assets regardless of the characterization. Even if you think that something may be separate property, list everything and review with your attorney

subcat_1.title: Temporary Support—How to Get What You Need

task_1.title: Prepare a document containing the facts about your financial need
task_1.description:
* Include your education, work history and earnings. If you have experienced any illnesses or handicaps that have precluded you from working, include the facts about it.
* Include the facts about any time you have taken off work to raise children or to support your husband.
* Use your income and expense declaration to show what you need to support your household.

task_2.title: Include facts about your husband’s ability to pay
task_2.description:
* Include your husband’s education, his work history and his earnings.
* Use tax returns to show what he has traditionally earned.

task_1.title: Conduct discovery

task_2.title: Evaluate different settlement scenarios

* Educate Yourself About the Process

subcat_1.title: Vocational Examination

task_1.title: If your husband’s income drops significantly after the divorce is filed or if he is unemployed, discuss with your attorney whether to request a vocational evaluation of him

task_2.title: If you are unemployed, ask your attorney if it would be beneficial for you to sit for a vocational evaluation to gather information and to be used as a defensive tactic

task_1.title: Executive Summary

task_2.title: Company Description

subcat_1.title: Reduce your exposure to spousal support if you are the breadwinner

task_1.title: Reduce the current household expenses
task_1.description: The monthly household expenses are used to determine “need,” which in turn is used to determine support.  Reducing the household expenses reduces the benchmark “need” utilized in the support calculation.

task_2.title: Establish a precedent of the husband supporting his own needs with little or no financial support from you
task_2.description: If he can meet his own needs, then he doesn’t have an argument that he needs support from you.

task_3.title: Help get the husband a job or more education
task_3.description: Whatever you can do to help him become self-sufficient will strengthen your argument that he does not need support from you.

task_4.title: Maximize time with the children
task_4.description: The more time they spend with you, the less you will owe in child support.

task_5.title: Allow a temporary disability to improve
task_5.description: If you suffer from a disability, it will minimize your support obligation.

task_6.title: Reduce income available for support
task_6.description: If income is trending down, it would make sense in holding off the divorce to use a lower income in calculating maintenance.

task_7.title: Request the husband undergo a vocational evaluation
task_7.description: if he is shirking his obligation to work or under earning, request he agree to submit to a vocational evaluation for purposes of imputing income in the support determination.

subcat_1.title: Crank Up the Income—Know What You’re Worth and Insist on It

task_1.title: How to get a raise if you work for a company
task_1.description:
* Find Out What the Competition is Being Paid
* Don’t Personalize It
* Consider Your Timing
* It’s Not About You, It’s About Them
* Prove Your Worth
* Know What You Want
* It’s Not Just About Pay

task_2.title: How to increase your income if you work for yourself
task_2.description:
* Don’t Undersell Yourself
* Increase Your Rate with Your Next Potential Prospect
* Raise Your Value

subcat_1.title: How to Use Social Media to Increase Business

task_1.title: Determine the best way to connect with prospects
task_1.description:
* Facebook for business-to-consumer sales
* Instagram and Pinterest increase visibility
* LinkedIn to connect with people at corporations that might be interested in your product or service
* Twitter can be used for all kinds of sales
* Blogs, live chats and comment sections on websites to generate leads

task_2.title: Join a community and create a persona
task_2.description:
* Build up a personal account
* Have conversations
* Become acquainted with the norms and expectations of the community

task_3.title: Connect
task_3.description:
* Friend, follow or connect with individuals with profiles that match your clients’.
* Conduct a search on each social networking website or use a resource like socialmention.com to find people who are talking about your industry or using related keywords.
* Comment on their posts, retweet them, answer a question, or share something they say.

task_4.title: Build relationships
task_4.description: Develop relationships, which will turn into leads.

task_5.title: Engage in a conversation
task_5.description:
* Create a Facebook group related to your product or service and invite prospects to join. Then, send targeted messages to members who are active within the group.
* Join the groups that your clients are members of on LinkedIn. Engage in conversation there by answering questions that are asked and showcasing your expertise at problem solving in a specific area.
* Listen to your prospects’ tweets and use them as trigger points to start a conversation on a business development call.

subcat_1.title: Handling Issues Concerning Your Children

task_1.title: Document any instances of abuse

task_2.title: Maximize Your Time With Your Children

subcat_1.title: How to Tell Your Children About the Divorce and Process it

task_1.title: Tell children about the divorce together, if possible

task_2.title: Answer children’s questions honestly, avoiding unnecessary details

task_3.title: Reassure children they are not to blame for divorce

task_4.title: Tell children they are loved and will be taken care of

task_5.title: Include the other parent in school and other activities

task_6.title: Be consistent and on time to pick up and return children

task_7.title: Develop a workable parenting plan that gives children access to both parents

task_8.title: Guard against canceling plans with children

task_9.title: Give children permission to have a loving, satisfying relationship with the other parent

task_10.title: Avoid putting children in the middle and in the position of having to take sides

task_11.title: Avoid pumping children for information about the other parent

task_12.title: Avoid arguing and discussing child support issues in front of children

task_13.title: Avoid speaking negatively about the other parent or using the child as a pawn to hurt the other parent

subcat_2.title: Know the Potential Signs of Stress in Your Children

task_1.title: Acting younger than their chronological age

task_2.title: Showing fear of being apart from parent(s)

task_3.title: Experiencing moodiness

task_5.title: Being manipulative

task_11.title: Displaying irrational fears and compulsive behavior

subcat_1.title: Be the Grown Up – Don’t Allow Children to Become Pawns in Divorce

task_1.title: Do not blame the kids’ Dad by using the word “your” with disdain

task_2.title: Do not trash-talk your ex in front of the kids

task_3.title: Do not squash all attempts for your ex to spend time with the kids

task_5.title: Do not use your children as messengers between you and your ex

task_6.title: Do not sabotage your ex to make yourself look like the better parent

task_7.title: Stop complaining to your kids about your ex

task_8.title: Do not compare your children to their father when they show similar behavior

subcat_1.title: How to Handle the Child Who is Acting Out

task_1.title: Establish and maintain routines

task_2.title: Allow your child to move between both parent’s homes without guilt

task_3.title: Respect each other’s rules and values

task_5.title: Offer limited choices

task_6.title: Make time for cuddling and fun

task_7.title: Resolving conflict with your spouse
task_7.description:
* Express your needs and wants clearly
* State your feelings in straight-forward “I” language
* Practice and rehearse

subcat_1.title: Parenting Plan—Making a Parenting Plan That Works for You and Your Kids

task_1.title: The 2-2-3 Schedule
task_1.description: Very young children typically do better with fewer days away from mom. Consider a 2-2-3 schedule for children under the age of five if both parents work.

task_2.title: The 2-2-5-5 Schedule
task_2.description: A 2-2-5-5 schedule divides the children’s time equally between the parents, but there is less switching back and forth than the 2-2-3 schedule.

task_3.title: The Alternating Weeks Schedule
task_3.description: Your child spends one week with one parent and the next week with the other parent. This schedule works well when your children are older.

subcat_1.title: Parenting Plan—How to Negotiate an Effective Parenting Plan

task_1.title: Come prepared

task_2.title: Be Calm

task_3.title: Take Turns Speaking and Listening

task_5.title: Have a Plan or Sticking to Your Plan

task_6.title: Consider Using a Therapist to Negotiate

subcat_1.title: Dating During Divorce

task_1.title: How to Handle the New Girlfriend
task_1.description:
* Be Secure in Your Relationship with Your Child
* Turn It into an Opportunity by Spending More Time with the Kids
* Make the Kids Your priority

task_2.title: When to Date
task_2.description: Talk to your divorce lawyer to find out how it will affect your case

subcat_1.title: Effective CoParenting

task_1.title: Parenting as a team
task_1.description:
* Rules--Establish consistent guidelines in both homes
* Discipline--follow similar systems of consequences for broken rules
* Schedule--aim for some consistency in your children’s schedules

task_2.title: Handling disagreements
task_2.description:
* Respect Can Go a Long Way
* Keep Talking
* Don’t Sweat the Small Stuff
* Compromise

task_3.title: Making transitions easier
task_3.description:
* When Your Child Leaves
    * *Help children anticipate change.* Remind kids they’ll be leaving for the other parent’s house at least a day before the switch.
    * *Double up.* To make packing simpler and make kids feel more comfortable when they are at the other parent's house, have kids keep certain basics—toothbrush, hairbrush, pajamas—at both houses.
    * *Pack in advance.*  Encourage packing familiar reminders like a special stuffed toy or photograph.
* When Your Child Returns
    * *Time to adjust.* Try to arrange returns so that you have time for a meal and down time before school starts.
    * *Keep things low-key.* When children first enter your home, try to have some down time together—read a book or do some other quiet activity.
    * *Allow the child space.* Children often need a little time to adjust to the transition. If they seem to need some space, do something else nearby, like prepare dinner.
    * *Establish a routine.* Play a game or prepare dinner every time your child returns. Kids thrive on routine—if they know exactly what to expect when they return to you it can help the transition.

task_1.title: Can you really afford the house on your own when the divorce is over?

task_2.title: Could you be better off taking other assets in exchange for your share of the family home?

task_3.title: Consider the many benefits of making a clean break by selling the marital home.

task_1.title: Consult a local realtor to find out what comparable homes are currently selling for near your home and what you can expect to net from a sale

task_5.title: What are your housing options where you live?

task_6.title: Are there rentals available where you live that meet your needs and are in the same school district?

subcat_1.title: Get Appraised—Obtain Appraisals of Real Estate for Use During Negotiations

task_1.title: Negotiate who will pay for the appraisal and repairs

task_2.title: Boost Your Home’s appraisal value
task_2.description:
* Patch the walls and paint.*
* Fix leaky faucets, broken windows and cracked ceilings.
* Clean up landscaping.
* Itemize your improvements.
* Jot down the repairs and updates you’ve made over the years, when you did them and how much they cost.
* Bring carpet, tile, windows and other permanent fixtures up to date.

task_3.title: Ask your attorney for a referral for an appraiser

task_4.title: Be at the house during the appraisal
task_4.description:
* If there have been positive changes to your neighborhood—like new schools or new roads—let the appraiser know.
* Provide the appraiser with itemizations for improvements, particularly things he may not notice like a new roof or insulation.

subcat_1.title: Downsizing—When Less is More

task_1.title: Assess Your Actual Needs
task_1.description:
* Take a walk through your house or apartment and evaluate everything you come across (furniture, books, food, etc.). Ask yourself if you've used it in the past year and, if not, get rid of it.
* Make room for the things you'll actually use.
* For stuff that you really have a hard time getting rid of, put the items in the garage. If you don't need or use them within 6 months, give, sell or throw them away.

task_2.title: Go Through Your Home, Every Cabinet, Shelf and Closet Should be Cleared
task_2.description: Only put back the things you couldn't live well without.

task_3.title: Measure Your Furniture and get room measurements of your new space.

task_4.title: Assess Your New Storage Areas
task_4.description: Assessing exactly how much of the new space is dedicated to storage will give you an idea of the volume of items you need to dispose of before moving in.

task_5.title: Ransack Your Old Storage Areas
task_5.description:
* Get rid of boxes of items that you haven’t used for years.
* Go through your bathroom cabinets, kitchen and “junk” drawers.
* Load up and drop off unwanted items at the nearest thrift shop.
* Join a Freecycle group to give stuff away (www.freecycle.org).
* If you live in an apartment building or townhouse complex, check notice boards and drop off areas for giving unwanted items to neighbors.
* Call up your friends and relatives and see what they need.

task_6.title: Sell Your Stuff
task_6.description:
* Have a yard sale (or a series of yard sales), or if you have a lot to sell quickly, consider a service to take care of it for you (e.g., Google liquidation estate content sales).
* Utilize Craigslist and eBay to sell off the best stuff.
* Used designer clothing can be resold in consignment shops.

task_8.title: Move Large Items First
task_8.description: Place furniture in the rooms as you go, according to the plan you made earlier.

task_9.title: Put Away Storage Items
task_9.description: Contained items that are meant for storage can be placed directly in their allotted spaces where they will be out of the way.

task_10.title: Organize Boxed Items
task_10.description:
* Your labeled boxes can now be put into their respective rooms and the unpacking can begin.
* Begin with the bathroom, as that is the room most likely to be needed immediately.

task_11.title: Organize Your Space as You Unpack
task_11.description: Utilize closet and cupboard storage solutions as you unpack. This way, more can be stored in these tight spaces and you will be setting a precedent for how your new, smaller space will be used.

subcat_1.title: At Home in Your Home

task_1.title: Replace your bedding

task_2.title: Paint the bedroom a different color

task_3.title: Get yourself new sleepwear and lingerie

task_4.title: Buy a new ring for a different finger

task_5.title: Replace artwork that you purchased with your spouse and that reminds you of him

task_6.title: Freshen up your bathroom with new towels

task_7.title: Pack up photos of the two of you and store them in the garage or attic

subcat_1.title: Create a Mindfulness Practice

task_1.title: Create a place in your home for an altar. Set aside time each day for meditation.

task_2.title: After quieting your mind, ask for help from whatever source you believe in (God, the universe, a Higher Power) to assist you with whatever might arise during the day.

task_3.title: Start a journal.

task_4.title: Read for at least 10 minutes from the books on the following list and commit to practice the truths revealed.  As you engage this practice, record its impact in your journal. Your life will change and it will be better
task_4.description:
* *Radical Acceptance* (Tara Brach)
* *Illuminata* (Marianne Williamson)
* *The Seven Spiritual Laws of Success* (Deepak Chopra)

subcat_1.title: Seek Help

task_1.title: Interview three therapists for yourself.  Ask your girlfriends for referrals, especially those who have gone through divorce

task_2.title: Review any signs of stress identified on the following list to determine if your children need therapy, and if so, ask for a recommendation from your therapist

subcat_1.title: Essentials v. Nonessentials—Identify Priorities and Eliminate Nonessentials

task_1.title: Get an early start each day

task_2.title: Make a list of the things that must get done each day

task_3.title: Pare the to-do list down to four to six tasks

task_5.title: Eliminate remaining nonessentials

task_6.title: Ask yourself throughout the day whether whatever you are doing at the moment is contributing to your freedom, independence and happiness. If no, eliminate it

subcat_1.title: Moving Through the Grieving Process During Divorce

task_1.title: Keep up your therapy appointments

task_2.title: Cry it out so you can eliminate those toxic emotions

task_3.title: Double down on your mindfulness practice

task_4.title: Write honestly in your journal about any addictive behaviors that are taking hold

task_5.title: If you are stuck in depression or self-medicating, consult your therapist about seeking an evaluation to determine whether short-term treatment of antidepressants may be helpful

subcat_1.title: Gratitude—Cultivate the Healing Power of Gratitude

task_1.title: Keep a Gratitude Journal
task_1.description:
* Who or what inspired me today?
* What brought me happiness today?
* What brought me comfort and deep peace today?

task_2.title: Write a Thank You Letter
task_2.description:
* Make a list of at least five people who have had a profound impact on your life.
* Choose one and write a thank you letter expressing gratitude for all the gifts you’ve received from that person.
* If possible, deliver your gratitude letter in person.

task_3.title: Take a Gratitude Walk
task_3.description:
* Set aside 20 minutes (or longer if you can) and walk in your neighborhood, through a park, around your office, or somewhere in nature. As you walk, consider the many things for which you are grateful:
    * nurturing relationships
    * material comforts
    * the body that allows you to experience the world
    * the mind that allows you to really understand yourself, and your essential spiritual nature

subcat_1.title: Radical Acceptance—Accepting What Is Within Your Power to Change Will Set You Free

task_1.title: Create a new mindset
task_1.description: While engaging in your mediation practice, repeat this mantra: **I may not be happy about this result, but I accept it.**

task_2.title: Change your perspective
task_2.description: Practice this mantra throughout the day when things don’t go as planned: **Perhaps there is another way to look at this.**

task_3.title: Choose peace of mind
task_3.description: Practice this mantra when the chatter in your head becomes deafening: **I’d rather be at peace than be right.**

subcat_1.title: Grit—Essential for Success

task_1.title: Find Your Purpose

task_2.title: Make a Plan

task_3.title: Go for It

task_5.title: Just Do It

subcat_1.title: Be Better, Not Bitter

task_1.description:
* Write a letter to your ex-husband expressing your feelings. When you are done, put the letter in an envelope, seal it and place it on your altar.  Each morning, for seven days, sit in quiet meditation before the altar with the intention of letting go of those negative emotions.
* On the seventh day, burn the letter.
* Sit in quiet meditation and visualize the negative emotions dissipating like the ashes of the letter. Ask that the new space created within yourself be filled with love and light.
